title: Pampered pets Great Dane Angus
story: David Grant thinks Angus has callus  (Image:  )A - I think Angus has a callus.A general veterinary examination would be useful to determine whether Angus is overweight or if there is any underlying disease such as an inactive thyroid gland or a secondary infection, which would need treatment.Calluses form when the skin is put under sustained pressure from lying for long periods on a hard surface.The skin becomes thickened and if it irritates the dog, licking and biting can cause an infection.                Pampered pets: What is the best treatment for fleas on my cat?                Pampered pets: Should I be worried about my dog&rsquos swollen lipAny area of the body that is regularly in contact with a hard surface can develop a callus.It is very common where there is little tissue between the skin and the underlying bone.Have a look at Angus&rsquos favourite resting places and make sure there is soft bedding.It can be tricky to encourage an old dog to sleep on a different surface.However, it&rsquos essential to prevent recurrence once your vet has things under control.&nbsp David Grant MBE was a vet at the RSPCA Harmsworth Hospital for Animals. Write to him at Express Yourself, 10 Lower Thames Street, London EC3R 6EN. He is unable to enter into correspondence

title: brexit news uk passport eu travel no deal brexit
story: If there is no deal many of the agreements within the EU will cease to apply for Britain which means UK citizens will need passports less than 10 years old and with three months validity left when they enter the EU.It also potentially means that UK driving licenses would cease to be valid in the EU so drivers wanting to use a vehicle in the EU will have to get an International Driver Permit (IDP).The same will apply to EU citizens wanting to visit Britain.According to the Schengen Border Code, third country passports must have been issued within the last 10 years on the date of arrival, and have at least 3 months' validity remaining on the date of intended departure from the last country visited in the Schengen area.Because non-Schengen nationals can remain in the area for 90 days, passport checks may actually require at least six months' validity on the date of arrival.                Martin Lewis Money Saving Expert on unannounced passport change                Brexit blue passports to return NEXT YEAR - this is how they'll be The Government's technical notice says: If you plan to travel to the Schengen area after 29 March 2019, to avoid any possibility of your adult British passport not complying with the Schengen Border Code we suggest that you check the issue date and make sure your passport is no older than 9 years and 6 months on the day of travel.If your passport does not meet these criteria, you may be denied entry to any of the Schengen area countries, and you should renew your passport before you travel.In a further complication, since 2001 some adult British passports have been issued with more than 10 years before they run out.This happened in cases where passports were renewed before expiring, meaning the time left on the old travel document was added to the new one.Post-Brexit passport design (Image: PA)In such a scenario, the passport holder would not be able to use the expiry date to check if it would be valid under the new rules.From the beginning of this month, extra validity is no longer being added to passports, with maximums now set at 10 years for adult documents and five for child passports.Other papers included information on space debris, environmental controls, business dealings and civil law.

title: Brexit news Theresa May Julia Hartley Brewer BBC question time conservative party chequers
story: The media star was speaking on the BBC&rsquos Question Time programme, which has just recommenced after Parliament returned from its annual summer recess.During the lively televised debate in Banbury, Oxfordshire, audience member George Stowe asked the panel whether the Tory party needed to &ldquotoss out Theresa May to save Brexit.Ms Hartley-Brewer emphatically replied: &ldquoYes. The most generous explanation for the Chequers agreement I can think of is that Theresa May was taken hostage by the Europhile bureaucrats in Whitehall, and when we saw that video of her dancing in Africa that was a proof of life video - it is the only explanation I can think of.The journalist and broadcaster offered that Mrs May had got herself elected as Tory leader by saying she would follow through on Brexit, then stood for election in June 2017 on a Brexit manifesto.                Brexit news: Theresa May urged to WIN BACK TRUST at Tory conference                BREXIT CRISIS: Carney boss warns no-deal could be like 2008 crashShe said: &ldquoThe Euro-sceptics in her party are accused of being rebels.&ldquoThey are not rebelling. She is rebelling against her own manifesto.&ldquoShe is the only captain of a ship who is running her own mutiny against herself.The newspaper columnist also argued there was a good reason why MPs chose to put the EU question to the public because the House of Lords and the House of Commons does not represent the British public on the issue.Julia Hartley-Brewer lambasted Theresa May claiming the PM is rebelling against her own manifesto (Image: BBC)The Question Time debate was held in Banbury, Oxfordshire (Image: BBC)She said: &ldquoAnd to keep saying, &lsquothere isn&rsquot a majority in the House of Commons,&rsquo I don&rsquot care!&ldquoThis is not a decision for the House of Commons this is a decision for the British people.&ldquoThey asked the question, we gave the answer, and we want the Brexit that we were promised.&ldquoAnd if Theresa May can&rsquot deliver it, she should go.                Jeremy Vine: Time's up for rival BBC show                 Question Time LIVE: Dimbleby joined by Theo Paphitis &amp Chris LeslieMs Hartley-Brewer joked that the images of Mrs May dancing were a 'proof of life video' (Image: )Following the dancing gaffe, Mrs May quipped she wouldn't be appearing on 'Strictly' any time soon (Image: )The BBC audience applauded Ms Hartley-Brewer&rsquos comments as Prison Minister Rory Stewart shook his head in disagreement.Defending the Government&rsquos position, he said: &ldquoWe have to be realistic. You have to understand that there are two sides in this.The Tory minister argued what the Prime Minister had put in place was clearly what the British people had voted for.He said: &ldquoShe has put in lines on free movement of people, lines on taking back control of our laws, lines on doing our own customs agreements.Prison Minister Rory Stewart weighed in on the debate and defended the Government's position (Image: BBC)The MP for Penrith and The Border suggested the Conservative Party&rsquos stance on Brexit was an indication it was moving into the political centre ground.He said: &ldquoThe fact that Julia is unhappy with this, and the fact that many Remain people in the audience are unhappy with this, probably indicates that we are moving into the centre ground.&ldquoAnd the centre ground is where we need to be on this.&ldquoThat is not a weakness. It is a strength.

title: Brexit news latest update UK EU space programme space debris asteroids earth
story: The warning is included in the second tranche of technical notices - 28 documents in all - released by the Government to provide guidance on the impact of exiting the EU without a Brexit agreement.One of the areas focuses on space and satellites, and more specifically the UK&rsquos involvement in the EU Space Surveillance and Tracking (EUSST) programme.This was established in 2014 and warns about debris orbiting the Earth that could pose a threat to satellites, and 're-entry warnings', which alert contributing nations to objects plummeting tens of thousands of miles towards the planet.The system went live in 2016 but is still not fully functional, with the UK opening a centre to provide warnings about the breakup of space debris above the Earth&rsquos atmosphere.                'Scrap Galileo prove how GREAT Britain is!' MEP trashes Juncker threat                Brexit news: Britain tells EU fund in place for OWN version of GalileoBut the latest document released by the Government on Wednesday warn the UK will not be able to take part in the EUSST programme in the event of a no-deal Brexit.It states that UK firms will not be able to contribute to providing services to the programme, take part in the scientific and technical groups to develop it further or be able to receive grant funding to pay for UK involvement.Welsh Labour MP for Cardiff Central Jo Stevens, who backs the anti-Brexit &lsquoBest for Britain&rsquo group, condemned the decision to eliminate the UK from the programme the cost of thousands of jobs and billions of pounds to the economy.She said: &ldquoIt is deeply worrying that the UK will be shut out of some of the most cutting-edge research in the world.Brexit news: The EU could stop warning the UK about potential deadly space debris (Image: )&ldquoThis research provides thousands of high-tech jobs and provides the economy billions every year.&ldquoTheresa May used to say Brexit wouldn&rsquot be the end of the world &ndash but actually it could be!&ldquoBy walking away from these collaborative projects, we will be isolating ourselves and having to start from scratch, spending a fortune when our European counterparts have already finished the job.But the Government paper does reveal the UK will at least continue to receive space, surveillance and tracking data from the US.                Brexit news: UK buoyed by EU's offer of Galileo access                 'No Europe, no Galileo' Juncker takes HUGE swipe at Brexit BritainTheresa May announced &pound92m seed funding for a British rival to Galileo (Image: )In the event of a no-deal Brexit, the Government papers says a small number of UK providers may still have EUSST programme delivery contracts in place in March 2019 but that these are expected to end before October 2020.It adds that EU businesses, academics and researchers are currently able to bid for contracts related to the programme.But it warns any EU firms &ldquocurrently or expecting to carry out contracts which involve partnership arrangements with UK businesses, academics and researchers may wish to contact the relevant contracting authority to make sure that arrangements are in place to ensure continued partnership complies with the conditions of the contract post exit and to avoid possible penalties.This comes as a separate notice revealed that British firms working on the EU&rsquos &pound8.9bn (&euro10bn) Galileo satellite navigation system programme could be axed from existing contracts in the event of a no-deal Brexit.Brexit news: The EUSST programme warns of debris orbiting the earth that could threaten satellites (Image: )The UK and EU have been at loggerheads about access to the programme over recent months, prompting Prime Minister Theresa May to announce &pound92m (&euro103m) seed funding for a British rival.Firms had already been told they could be blocked from bidding for new work on the programme.But a technical paper from the Department for Business, Energy and Industry Strategy warned the UK would no longer play any part in the development of Galileo.Britain wants to remain part of the programme if a Brexit deal can be reached but the EU is insisting full membership of the programme is only open to member states.

Now it has been another two years.                Question Time LIVE: Dimbleby joined by Theo Paphitis &amp Chris Leslie                &lsquoIf May can&rsquot deliver Brexit, she MUST go&rsquo - Julia Hartley-Brewer &ldquoWe have known all along that everybody in Parliament, every MP, doesn&rsquot want to leave Europe. We have known that from the start.&ldquoJust get out. Get out now as quickly as possible.Another audience member offered his views that former Brexit Secretary David Davis, who resigned from the cabinet following the unveiling of Theresa May&rsquos Chequers proposals, was the standard-bearer for the Leave process.He said: &ldquoDavid Davis was the champion for Brexit.Mrs May has failed the British people, a Question Time audience member suggested last night (Image: BBC&bullEPA)The debate was held in Banbury, Oxfordshire  (Image: BBC)&ldquoHe has done a lot of the negotiations, he is one of the most credible men in British politics and he has walked away.&ldquoYou must ask the question, why?The audience member suggested the EU&rsquos chief negotiator Michel Barnier had recently appeared to have changed his tact towards the UK and was suddenly acting in a friendlier fashion.He said: &ldquoYou must also ask yourself the question, why?                The Chase: Bradley Walsh takes swipe at Nick Clegg                &lsquoRe-run of Brexit vote BETRAYS democracy&rsquo - Julia Hartley-BrewerPolicy wonk Faiza Shaheen also took part in the animated TV debate (Image: BBC)&ldquoThe answer is: the Chequers deal is not credible.&ldquoIt is credible for Europe. It is not credible for the people of Great Britain.Prospective Parliamentary candidate for the Labour Party, Faiza Shaheen, also took part in the animated TV debate in Banbury, Oxfordshire.Ms Shaheen, who is director of a think tank called the Centre for Labour and Social Studies, claimed the Government was incompetent.Long-standing TV presenter David Dimbleby chaired the lively debate in Oxfordshire (Image: BBC)The left-wing policy wonk said: &ldquoWe need policies that address the issues.She added: &ldquoFor me, I struggle with a People&rsquos Vote because I think it could get very nasty, Brexit has already been incredibly isive.&ldquoIf we want to address the issues relating to Brexit, we need broader policy changes.Ms Shaheen, who called for a &ldquoBrexit package on policy, claimed prominent Brexiteer figures such as Jacob Rees-Mogg needed to be held accountable.She said: &ldquoIf it is true that we can&rsquot get the Brexit deal they said we could, then I think there is a question about whether we need to go back and say, &lsquowhat does Brexit look like?&rsquo&ldquoWe can&rsquot keep going round in circles, it is just not possible.She added: &ldquoThe best way I have heard it described is: we are like scrambled eggs and you can&rsquot &lsquounscramble&rsquo scrambled eggs.

title: Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby zero hour contract amazon news
story: Speaking at the TUC Congress in Manchester on Wednesday, Justin Welby, claimed the Universal Credit system should be scrapped and high earners should be forced to pay more tax.He hit out at zero-hours contracts, noting they were &ldquothe reincarnation of ancient evil and criticised Amazon for paying &ldquoalmost nothing in taxes.However, it emerged today that at least two of Church of England cathedrals are advertising zero-hours contract jobs and Amazon is one of the Church of England&rsquos major investments.Tory MP Ben Bradley commented on Justin Welby&rsquos behaviour saying: &ldquoIt&rsquos particularly hypocritical when, just like the Labour Party, he publicly condemns zero-hours contracts whilst privately his Church are currently advertising zero-hours jobs.                Archbishop of Canterbury told to quit after comparing trade unions ...                Outrage after Canterbury Archbishop sides with trade union activists&ldquoHe personally expects workers in the gig economy to deliver his books to your house when you purchase them on the &lsquoevil&rsquo capitalist Amazon website, so good to see he's thought his comments through.&ldquoYou'd like to think the Archbishop could practise what he preaches, but apparently not.Reverend Ray Anglesea, a United Reformed Church minister who worked on a zero-hours contract in one cathedral bookshop, also criticised the Archbishop for his incoherent remarks and suggested he might have done well to have put his own house in order before addressing the conference.In a letter to the Times, Revered Anglesea wrote: &ldquoWhat the Most Reverend Justin Welby did not disclose was how many of his cathedrals are zero contract hour employers and how many cathedral employees have no job certainty, no sick or holiday pay, and no maternity cover.Justin Welby has been branded a &ldquohypocrite for heavily criticising Amazon and the gig economy (Image: Getty) It emerged the Church of England uses zero-hour contracts and invests in the giant tech company (Image: Getty)The Archbishop&rsquos spokeswoman told the publication most senior of clerics had made clear his views on zero-hours contracts in the speech he delivered in Manchester.Regarding its investment in Amazon, a Church of England spokesman said: The Church Commissioners have previously been on the record that we consider aggressive tax avoidance or abusive tax arrangements to be both a business risk and an ethical issue.&ldquoAs with other issues, we take the view that it is most effective to be in the room with these companies seeking change as a shareholder.We continue to work with other shareholders to tackle this issue via engagement with companies and their managers.Justin Welby was also under fire for claiming Jesus had the same values as trade unionists (Image: Getty)Amazon denied the claims made by the cleric and confirmed it paid all taxes required in the UK and every country where we operate.The Archbishop of Canterbury's speech in Manchester did not only spark controversy over Amazon and zero-hours contract.Justin Welby was also under fire for claiming Jesus had the same values as trade unionists.The head of the Church of England was told to quit and join the Labour Party after saying trade unions should hold big businesses to account for their actions.

title: uk weather forecast Hurricane Helene path map UK weather forecast latest update
story: A video showing a map from the US National Hurricane Centre revealed the path of Hurricane Helene set to head towards the UK.&nbspThe interactive chart shows the predicted wind speed reaching up to 100mph by the time the hurricane gets to Britain.Forecasters have warned the Atlantic hurricane will bring an area of low pressure sparking temperatures to soar and potentially causing a mini-heatwave.The latest NHC map shows Helene moving in an easterly direction across the north Atlantic as of 10am BST (5am AST) on Thursday, packing winds of up to 100 miles per hour.                BBC Weather: Hurricane Helene could bring BOILING temperatures to UK                Hurricane Helene: Terrifying map shows storm BULLDOZING its way to UKAn accompanying NHC advisory suggested a turn toward the north-northeast with an increase in&nbspforwarding&nbspspeed was expected tonight.This is likely to be followed by a turn toward the northeast over the weekend.If it maintains that course, it could make landfall on the south coast of Ireland and west coast of the UK at 1pm BST (8am AST) Monday morning.Met Office meteorologist Alan Deakin said: &ldquoHurricane Helene may influence things in combination with an area of low pressure over the coming days.Hurricane Helene: Winds on collision course with the UK at up to 100mph speed (Image: NHC)&ldquoAreas of low pressure containing what&rsquos left of Storm Helene will still provide moisture and energy which will impact the UK quite a bit as we go into the early part of next week.&ldquoThere is a lot of uncertainty around the development of that low-pressure system.BBC Weather&nbspforecaster Matt Taylor warned that weather uncertainty could be sending a mini-heatwave our way &mdash or equally possibly, stormy conditions.Mr Taylor told&nbspBBC&nbspviewers: &ldquoWe&rsquove been talking&nbspHurricane Florence, well what about Hurricane Helene. It&rsquos in the Eastern Atlantic and is going to be creeping towards us.&ldquoIt will no longer be a hurricane by any means when it gets close to us.&ldquoThere&rsquos an area of low pressure but it will be crucial to dictating our weather next week.He continued: &ldquoExactly where it goes beyond Monday is uncertain at the moment, if it moves North then it will be dragging in some very humid air and some sunshine, but if it moves across us there&rsquos potential for stormy conditions next week.&ldquoThere&rsquos a lot of uncertainty though.

title: UK weather forecast Hurricane Helene path map MET Office latest update London weather
story: The Met Office has claimed Helene, which is currently bulldozing its way through the Atlantic, could bring thermometers as high as 26C in the London area, while reaching only 6C in Scotland.Marco Petagna, a Met Office forecaster, said: &ldquoStorm Helene is still in the Atlantic but it could have an influence in Britain next week.&ldquoRemnants of that system could bring wet weather across western parts of the UK on Tuesday and we still need to keep an eye on it.&ldquoBut it could have a positive effect on eastern parts because it could also bring tropical air.                Hurricane Florence DOWNGRADED to Category 1 before US impact Speaking to The Sun, Mr Petegna added: &ldquoThe London area could see temperatures reach 26C on Tuesday because of the very warm air coming its way.&ldquoOn Saturday it will be dry and bright across many parts and temperatures could reach 21C in the South East.&ldquoIt will be significantly colder in northern parts with temperatures being as low as 6C in Scotland.Describing the conditions for Sunday, the Met Office forecaster said &ldquoit will start to get warmer with London and Kent seeing 23C.Hurricane Helene will split the nation with a large and abnormal temperature ide (Image: Natweather)Helene, currently in the Atlantic, is on a collision path with the UK (Image: NHC)However, Emma Smith, said more details will emerge within the next day over what impact the storm might have.She said: Helene is moving up from the Atlantic towards us.Hurricane Joyce is also in the Atlantic so we need to see how those two systems are going to move around each other because that could have an impact.It looks like Helene will move towards Ireland on Tuesday morning.                Hurricane Florence: Model shows HORRIFIC storm effect on Carolinas                TYPHOON TERROR: Mangkhut with power of 500,000 NUKES hits PhilippinesThermometres could see temperatures as high as 26C in the London area on Tuesday (Image: Getty)It's possible that the west coast of Wales and Cornwall could get some winds as well, but we will get a clearer picture of what to expect very soon.Helene is one of three &ldquolife-threatening hurricanes moving through the Atlantic behind Hurricane Florence and Isaac.Hurricane Florence has sparked mass evacuations as it charges towards landfall in the US, along with the East Coast.Florence has been downgraded to a category one hurricane stormy but is still considered dangerous and life-threatening.The Met Office warned temperatures in Scotland could be as low as 6C (Image: Getty)Hurricane Isaac, which is also brewing in the Atlantic, is expected to hit Venezuela and the Dominican Republic on Saturday.Although Helene is currently classified as a hurricane, continued weakening is forecast over the next couple of days.It may be downgraded to a tropical storm today.

title: BBC Weather forecast UK latest update track Friday weekend today September 2018
story: BBC Weather forecaster Matt Taylor told BBC viewers that persistent rain will be hitting parts of England, Scotland and Northern Ireland with some heavy bursts battering parts of the country throughout the weekend.Tempertures will start to rise however, as humid air is blown our way as the last remnants of Hurricane Helene approach us.&nbspMr Taylor told viewers this morning: &ldquoIt&rsquos a bit of a mixed day, and a bit of a mixed weekend.&ldquoOut there today some of you will have to grab an umbrella, grab something waterproof before you head out, particularly in the North and the West.                BBC Weather: Hurricane Helene could bring BOILING temperatures to UK                BBC weather forecast UK: UNSETTLED showers to dampen Britain &ldquoThere&rsquos going to be rain and times, but it&rsquos already starting to turn that little bit more persistent.&ldquoThe rain will become a bit more lengthy in duration across Western Scotland and Northern Ireland, and indeed into the North West of England.Those in the South and the East will see drier and warmer weather with temperatures reaching up to 19C in London today.Mr Taylor continued: &ldquoAcross England and Wales, there will be a few scattered showers around, some dry and sunny weather to the South and East, and across Northern Scotland for the day, things will brighten up.BBC Weather forecast: Warmer weather this weekend but uncertainty ahead due to Hurricane Helene (Image: BBC )&ldquoIt&rsquos not going to rain all day, long, there will still be some drier moments.This afternoon will be blustery with heavy outbreaks of rain drenching many areas of the country.The BBC forecaster told viewers: &ldquoLooking at the details for the afternoon, we&rsquoll have a bit of a Westerly breeze, but any showers towards Southern counties of England, towards South East and Eastern England will be very few and far between, she sunny spells here.&ldquoTowards the West, temperatures will generally be in the mid to high teens, across the North of England, Southern Scotland and Ireland there will be further outbreaks of rain, some heavy bursts at times but with Northern Scotland seeing some brighter skies.&ldquoAs we go into tonight we&rsquove still got that central zone of cloud with occasional rain with showers in Northern Scotland.&ldquoWe&rsquove got some lengthy clearer skies across East Anglia although rural areas will drop down into single figures and rural parts of North East Scotland there could be some frost around into tomorrow morning.Saturday morning will be drier and brighter, but it could be a washout Saturday night, with a deluge of rain threatening to batter much of the country in the evening.Mr Taylor said: &ldquoIt will be a lovely bright start across the South and East and will be a dry day by and large. Still the occasional showers in Northern England, Southern Scotland and Northern Ireland and the rain turns a bit more persistent to the West of Northern Ireland.&ldquoBut, many of us should actually get away with a dry day on Saturday and in the South West, it will start to feel just that little bit milder.&ldquoBit of a wet night though on Saturday to get us into Sunday, and in Scotland and Northern Ireland and as a weather front moves its way Southwards there will be outbreaks of rain throughout the day.In the Midlands and East Anglia temperatures could reach up to 22C.Mr Taylor said that temperatures will be rising throughout Sunday and towards the new working week, but uncertain weather is ahead with Hurricane Helene on the horizon.&ldquoTemperatures will be climbing up a little bit, and start to get a bit more of a humid feel and we will see temperatures climb a bit into Monday too.&ldquoBut a bit of uncertainty about next weeks forecast, there&rsquos a chance we could see some very wet and windy weather, for the remnants of Hurricane Helene.

title: Hurricane Florence path tracker LIVE NOAA evacuation map Category 5 Carolina Virginia
story: Hurricane Florence may have slightly weakened but the barrelling storm is still expected to make a direct hit on North Carolina with 110mph winds.The swirling storm howled closer to shore on Thursday, threatening to unleash life-threatening storm surge, surf, days of torrential rain and severe flooding.The storm will hit as a category 2 hurricane but Florence has caused the evacuation of some 1.5 million people with millions more likely to see some impact from the howling winds.Express brings you all the latest path and tracking news on Hurricane Florence below. All times in BST.                Hurricane Florence tracker: 'STORM OF A LIFETIME' to batter US coast                Hurricane Florence projected path: Florence to STALL over CarolinasHurricane Florence path tracker: The estimated arrival time of winds (Image: NHC )5.47pm update:&nbspDon&rsquot relax, don&rsquot get complacentThe Carolinas have begun to face the effects of Hurricane Florence, as heavy rainbands with tropical-storm-force winds have started to spread across the outer banks and coastal southeastern North Carolina.A life-threatening storm surge is still expected, despite the hurricane being downgraded to a Category 2 from a Category 4.The storm is now only 145 miles east-southeast from Wilmington, North Carolina, approaching the coast at a speed of 10mph (17kmh).North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper said on Thursday morning: &ldquoCatastrophic effects will be felt outside the center of the storm due to storm surge surge as high as 9 to 13 feet.&ldquoThat&rsquos the second story of a house. Tens of thousands of structures are expected to be flooded, and many more by rising rivers and creeks.He added: &ldquoDon&rsquot relax, don&rsquot get complacent. Stay on guard. This is a powerful storm that can kill. Today the threat becomes a reality.5.11pm update: Animals in dangerSealife at three major aquariums are preparing to face Hurricane Florence alone.Animal handlers at the three aquariums located on the vulnerable Outer Banks barrier islands and other threatened coastal areas, had no choice but to leave on Wednesday after making last-minute preparations.The animals are part of our family, said Danielle Bolton, spokeswoman for the Pine Knoll Shores aquarium, which closed to the public on Tuesday. It is very emotional having to close and not know exactly what's going to happen.The animals got fed as much as they could the last few days, Bolton said.Hurricane Florence path tracker LIVE: Florence as seen from the International Space Station (Image: Alexander Gerst)4.44pm update:&nbspHurricane Florence could &ldquokill a lot of peopleOfficials have warned Hurricane Florence could &ldquokill a lot of people as the storm begins its onslaught on the Carolinas.Brock Long, Federal Emergency Management Agency (Fema) administrator, said the inland flooding could result in a lot of deaths.Even though Florence has been downgraded to a Category 2 with 105mph (165kmh), Mr Long said it remained very dangerous.He told reporters on Thursday, the wind speed of Florence has reduced but the hurricane-force wind shield had expanded and total predictions were unchanged.Mr Long said: &ldquoSo this is a very dangerous storm. Inland flooding kills a lot of people unfortunately and that&rsquos what we&rsquore about to see.He added: &ldquoYour time is running out. The ocean is going to start rising.3.35pm update: Hurricane Florence downgraded to a Category 2 hurricaneHurricane Florence was downgraded to a Category 2 on the five-step Saffir-Simpson scale, according to the NHC.The storm was about 165 miles (265km) east of Wilmington, North Carolina at 9am EDT (2pm BST) but tropical storm-strength winds and heavy rains were already hitting North Carolina&rsquos Outer Banks barrier islands.The intense rain was forecast to extend as far inland as the Appalachians, affecting parts of Alabama, Tennessee, Kentucky and West Virginia.Emergency preparations included activating more than 2,700 National Guards troops, stockpiling food, setting up shelters, switching traffic patterns so major roads led away from shore, and securing 16 nuclear power reactors in the Carolinas and Virginia.Hurricane Florence tracker: Residents in an evacuation shelter in North Carolina (Image: Getty )2.29pm update: Florence's impacts begin to be felt in North CarolinaHeavy rainbands and tropical storm force winds are spreading across the North Carolina outer banks.Life threatening storm surge and rainfall is expected imminently.The latest NHC discussion read: &ldquoAircraft and satellite wind data show that Florence is a large hurricane. &nbsp&ldquoLife-threatening storm surge, heavy rainfall, and damaging wind will cover a large area regardless of exactly where the center of Florence moves.2.11pm update: Facts about Carolina hurricanesA category 5 hurricane has never struck the CarolinasThe only category 4 hurricanes to hit the region were Hazel (1954), Gracie (1959), and Hugo (1989).Hurricane Fran was the last major hurricane to make landfall in North Carolina in 1996Hurricane Florence: Flooding is likely to hit parts of the Carolinas (Image: ACCUWEATHER)2.03pm update: Florence to hit imminentlyThe NHC latest advisory read: On the forecast track, the centre of Florence will approach the coasts of North and South Carolina later today, then move near or over the&nbspcoast of southern North Carolina and eastern South Carolina in the hurricane warning area tonight and Friday.A slow motion over eastern South Carolina is forecast Friday night through Saturday night.1.00pm update: Florence to unleash CATASTROPHIC rainHurricane Florence is on track to hit North Carolina's coast today.And&nbspcurrent forecasts suggest a foot of rain could fall, leading to catastrophic flash flooding and major river flooding.Strength, track and forward speed of Florence will be the major players in determining the scope and amount of rainfall and correspondingly the severity of inland flooding, according to AccuWeather Hurricane Expert Dan Kottlowski.12.40pm update: Florence reach expands as hurricane approaches landfallHurricane Florence is no longer considered a major hurricane, likely to be a category 2 when it makes landfall.But despite some weakening, the hurricane's reach has expanded, threatening residents from Georgia to Virginia.Even Maryland, which will not see a direct hit, has declared a state of emergency.Hurricane Florence path update: Florence will make landfall today (Image: CNN)12.21pm update: Hurricane conditions expected imminentlyResidents have been warned to expect hurricane conditions to begin from 12 hours onwards, the US National Hurricane Center (NHC) said its lateset update.In a tweet, the weather agency wrote: &ldquoDo not focus on the wind speed category of #Hurricane #Florence! Life-threatening storm surge flooding, catastrophic flash flooding and prolonged significant river flooding are still expected.11.47am update: Three aquariums facing&nbspHurricane Florence alone after handlers forced to leaveAnimal handlers at North Carolina's three major aquariums, which are all located on the vulnerable Outer Banks barrier islands, had no choice but to leave after making last-minute preparations.The animals are part of our family, said Danielle Bolton, spokeswoman for the Pine Knoll Shores aquarium, which closed to the public on Tuesday.It is very emotional having to close and not know exactly what's going to happen.The animals got fed as much as they could the last few days, Bolton said.Sharks can go two to three weeks without eating. However, we don't normally let them go that long in the aquarium, Bolton said. We might find one or two of the smaller fish missing. We hope that's not gonna happen.11.30am update: Dozens of cities to face severe weather warnings todayTo find out which towns and cities are affected, read more here.Hurricane Florence path: This satellite image from the NOAA shows the storm's strength (Image: NOAA)10.36am update: Outer rain bands now beginning to hit North CarolinaThe NHC warned the outer rain bands of Hurricane Florence are now swiftly approaching the coast of North Carolina this morning.Life threatening storm surge and rainfall is expected imminently&nbsp10.23am update: The Atlantic is facing a barrage of hurricanes and typhoonsHurricane Florence now has company in the Atlantic ocean as she is joined by multiple storms.Hurricane Helene is currently boasting 90mph winds, while ex-hurricane Isaac will bash the Lesser Antilles with 60mph winds this week.We also have subtropical storm Joyce forming in the Atlantic, currently with winds of 40 knots.But the Atlantic is not the only region with fierce storms raging.In the Pacific, Super Typhoon Mangkhut is producing winds of 170 mph and enormous waves as it treks about 200 miles west of Guam.And Tropical Storm Barijat is passing south of Hong Kong this week also.And Tropical Depression Olivia, which was Hurricane strength last week, is still swirling in the Central Pacific.Hurricane tracker: This map shows all the storms raging right now (Image: CYCLOCANE)9.55am update:&nbspHurricane Florence is moving closer to the coast of North and South CarolinaBarrelling hurricane Florence is expected to bring a life-threatening storm surge, the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC) said on Thursday.The centre of Florence, a Category 2 hurricane, will approach the coasts of North and South Carolina on Thursday, the NHC said.The storm was expected to weaken after it moved inland.The Atlantic hurricane is located about 280 miles (450 kilometers) east-southeast of Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, packing maximum sustained winds of 110 miles per hour (175 kmh), the NHC said.9.10am update: 10 million under warning or watchThe National Weather Service said more than 10 million people live in areas under warnings or watches for hurricane- or tropical storm- force winds.Hurricane Florence: NASA took this stunning satellite picture (Image: NASA)8.58am update: Officials warns residents to get out NOWThe time to prepare is almost over, North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper told a morning news conference.Disaster is at the doorstep and it's coming in.Tens of thousands of homes and businesses could be flooded in North Carolina alone, Governor&nbsp&nbspwarned.Georgia Governor Nathan Deal issued an emergency declaration for all 159 counties in his state. Similar declarations were made earlier in North and South Carolina, Virginia, Maryland and the District of Columbia.More than 1 million people have been ordered to evacuate the coastlines of the Carolinas and Virginia. By late Wednesday, authorities in North Carolina reported nearly 7,000 evacuees staying in 71 emergency shelters throughout the state.8.30am update: TO RECAPHurricane Florence has been downgraded to a category two stormOfficials still warn of a disaster at the doorstepFlorence's winds have dropped to 110mph (175kmh) from 140mph recorded yesterdaySome 10 million people are now under some form of storm watch or warningGeorgia has joined&nbspNorth and South Carolina, Virginia, Maryland and Washington DC to declare a state of emergencyHurricane Florence path map: Florence has been building in the Atlantic (Image: NOAA)6.41am update: Georgia brewery switches to drinking water to help&nbsprescue&nbspeffortAn Anheuser-Busch brewer in Georgia has switched from making beer to canning water in an effort to help those affected by Hurricane Florence.The brewer made the decision after being asked by the American Red Cross to pause beer production and produce canned water instead.It is preparing to send 300,000 cans of drinking water to those affected by the hurricane.5.30 update: Florence forecast to make landfall as Category 2 hurricane&nbspHurricane Florence has weakened some more and is now forecast by the National Hurricane Centre to make landfall on Friday as a Category 2 hurricane.&nbspHowever&nbsphurricane expert Dr Rick Knabb warns: &ldquoYes good news that intensity of Florence has come down, to lessen wind damage somewhat.&nbsp&ldquoBut forecasts for life-threatening storm surge and rain-induced flooding have not changed!&ldquoLarge size and slower forward motion as Florence comes ashore&nbspare&nbspbad news.&nbsp&ldquoStill expect power outages.&nbspHurricane Florence live: Barrelling winds will hit the coast (Image: )4.25 update: Florence weakens to Category 2 hurricane&nbspHurricane Florence has weakened somewhat to a Category 2 hurricane.&nbspMaximum sustained wind speeds have dropped to 110 miles per hour.&nbspHowever the storm remains highly dangerous and could cause feet of rain and a massive storm surge in parts of the Carolinas.&nbsp3.39am update: Google activates &lsquoSOS Alerts&rsquo emergency system&nbspInternet giant Google has activated its SOS Alerts system, which are designed to make emergency information more accessible during natural or human caused disasters.&nbspGoogle CEO Sundar Pichai tweeted: &ldquoWe&rsquove activated our SOS Alert for Hurricane Florence to provide relevant emergency info to those who may be in the storm&rsquos path.&nbsp&ldquoPlease stay safe.&nbsp3.17 update: &ldquoDisaster is at the doorstep&nbspNorth Carolina Governor Roy Cooper has warned state residents: &ldquoDisaster is at the door and is coming in.&nbsp&ldquoIf you are on the coast there is still time to get out safely.&nbspSouth Carolina Governor Henry McMaster had a similar message saying: &ldquoThis hurricane is bringing more rain than any other hurricane.&nbspHe said that after rainfall starts to fall this week it could continue until Monday.&nbspHurricane Florence path: Latest NOAA update gives the storms path (Image: EPA)3.00 update: Parris Island Marines graduate early due to Florence&nbspDozens of trainees at the Marine training base on Parris Island, South Carolina, graduated early due to Hurricane Florence.&nbspThe group, who had been due to graduate on Friday in front of their families, instead graduated on Wednesday at a closed ceremony.&nbspHowever a 25 minute video of the ceremony was posted on the Marine Corps Facebook page.&nbsp2.41 update: Size of Hurricane Florence has increased&nbspHurricane Florence may have lost some strength today, going from a Category 4 to Category 3, but it has also increased significantly in size.&nbspMeteorologist Jim Cantore warns: &ldquoEven though we have seen Florence weakening some today its important to note the size of the hurricane and tropical storm wind fields have expanded.&nbsp&ldquoTropical force winds are almost 400 miles across and the hurricane winds are 140 miles across.&ldquoDon&rsquot focus on the category. &nbsp2.26 update: Airbnb allows users to offer free shelter to Florence evacuees&nbspOnline room renting service Airbnb is allowing users to offer free accommodation to those retreating from Hurricane Florence.&nbspThe company tweeted: &ldquoAirbnb has activated our host community to open their homes for $0 for those who have been evacuated form their homes as a result of Hurricane Florence.&nbsp &nbsp2.16 update: Facebook group helps house Florence evacuees&nbspA Facebook group is being used to offer shelter to some of the thousands fleeing Hurricane Florence.&nbspThe closed group, &ldquoHurricane Florence Lodging for Evacuees, reportedly has over 3,500 members with many offering accommodation to those dodging the storm.&nbspInterested users have to apply to join.&nbspOne of the administrations, Katlyn McBrayer, told Fox News: &ldquoAll these people open up their homes for free.&nbsp&ldquoA lot of them will allow your pets to come in, some of them will allow you to bring your livestock, your horses.&nbsp1.54am: Georgia declares state of emergency&nbspThe governor of Georgia has declared a state of emergency in all 159 of the states counties.&nbspIn a statement governor Nathan Deal said Georgia is: &ldquoMobilising all available resources to ensure public safety ahead of Hurricane Florence.&nbsp&ldquoI encourage Georgians to be prepared for the inland effects of the storm as well as the ensuing storm surge in coastal areas.&nbsp1.31am update: Pence cancels Georgia trip to respond to hurricane&nbspVice-President Pence has cancelled a planned trip to Georgia to help deal with the hurricane.&nbspAccording to a statement he will: &ldquoRemain in Washington DC to monitor the federal response.&nbspMeanwhile according to the official White House Twitter account: &ldquoHurricane Florence poses a catastrophic threat to millions living in North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia and Virginia.&nbsp&ldquoTo all in the path of these storms: Be safe, be ready and follow the advice of local officials.0.30am update:&nbspTropical Storm strength winds expected Thursday morning&nbspTropical Storm strength winds are expected to start hitting the North Carolina coast on Thursday morning.&nbspHurricane and storm serge warning remain in place for South Santee River in South Carolina, to Duck in North Carolina, including Pamlico and Albemarle Sounds.&nbspPresident Trump made a statement on the storm during a Medal of Honour reception at the White House.&nbspHe said: &ldquoMy administration is in close coordination with state and local authorities and FEMA has already placed extensive resources on the ground.&nbsp&ldquoWe are ready, but this is going to be one of the biggest ones to ever hit our country.&nbsp&nbspHurricane Florence: Winds will start to hit the region on Thursday (Image: )Wednesday 12 September&nbsp23.40 update: Virginia Beach high school open to evacuees&nbspThe Kellam High School in Virginia Beach has opened for evacuees looking to avoid Hurricane Florence.&nbspResidents have been filmed arriving with large bags of food, drink and personal possessions.&nbsp23:20 update: &ldquoStorm of a lifetime on its wayThe National Weather Service has warned that Hurricane Florence: &ldquoWill likely be the storm of a lifetime for portions of the Carolina coast.&nbspHurricane Florence, now a Category 3 storm, is moving northwest towards the Carolinas.&nbspMeteorologist Mike Smith reports: &ldquoIt appears a major flood is on the way in the Middle Atlantic region.&nbsp&ldquoIt is likely some areas will flood that have never flooded before.&nbspMeanwhile the National Hurricane Centre are warning: &ldquoThere is a high to moderate risk of flash flooding from Florence across eastern North Carolina and extreme eastern South Carolina on Friday.&nbsp8.50pm update: Carolina to be without power, affecting millionsDuke Energy North and South Carolina's major energy suppier, said that the storm could see up to three million customers siurviving without power.The latest predictions also state that people could be left powerless for weeks to come after the storm has passed.&nbspThere is the possibility that Florence will continue to weaken, so these numbers are subject to change in the future.&nbspMany title: EU news hungary article 7 antonio tajani malta slovakia
story: Both countries will have their rule of law investigated (Image: )The Slovakian cabinet will be at the Hungarian border in Kosice to celebrate the centenary of the founding of former sovereign state Czechoslovakia when MEPs from the civil liberties committee touch down in Bratislava.Meanwhile, the Maltese government will be in the Austrian city of Salzburg for a gathering the Brussels officials really should be aware of - the EU leaders summit.The cock-ups beg the question of whether bungling MEPs had actually checked the nations&rsquo calendars before making attempts to schedule meetings with their two member states.MEPs are summoning Malta&rsquos Prime Minister Joseph Muscat and Slovakian leader Peter Pellegrini to investigate allegations of corruption and organised crime after journalists Daphne Caruana Galizia and J&aacuten Kuciak were killed in the two countries.                Farage predicts post-Brexit REBELLION from Hungary and Poland                Hungary furious at Merkel as EU takes control of borders The death of Mr Kuciak in Velka Maca, south-west Slovakia, triggered former prime minister Robert Fico to step down, with Mr Pellegrini replacing him in March this year.Both countries will have their rule of law investigated after European Parliament President Antonio Tajani criticised MEPs for seemingly not acting on the countries, while punishing Hungary.MEPs earlier this week voted to trigger Article 7 proceedings against Hungary, which could lead to the country being banned from voting in EU matters, amid claims their domestic activity has broken the EU rules of law.Mr Tajani told radio station Talk24: &ldquoWhy was nothing done then against countries like Malta and Slovakia, when you had two journalists killed here, and in the case of Slovakia, leading to the resignation of a centre-left prime minister?                Italy backs Orban as EU threatens to strip Hungary's voting rights                France hails EU move to sanction Hungary as Orban FROZEN OUT Investigative journalist Mr Kuciak and his fianc&eacute Martina Kusnirova were murdered earlier this year.He was working on a shock report that gave a meticulous account of the ties between the Slovakian government and the Italian mafia which had been accused to defrauding the EU of subsidy funds.On the morning of February 26, police were called to the couple&rsquos home by concerned family members after neither answered their phones.They were found dead having been shot in the head and chest.Antonio Tajani criticised MEPs for seemingly not acting on the countries (Image: )In the murder of Ms Caruana, a car bomb was planted in her Peugeot 108 on October 16 last year.It exploded, killing her instantly.She had been on her way to her home in Bidnija at the time.In the wake of her death, she had filed a police report that said she had been threatened two weeks before hand.Investigative journalist Mr Kuciak and his fianc&eacute Martina Kusnirova were murdered (Image: )She had been involved in exposing the Panama Papers, documents that had been leaked to the press showing financial information of more than 214,488 offshore entities.But the meetings with Mr Pelligrini on September 17 and Mr Muscat&rsquos three days later on September 20 may have to be rescheduled for when both leaders are available.

title: national 4pm finish day 2018 friday leave work early
story: Here’s all you need to know about the one day where you just might be able to get away with an early exit.Devised by energy drink firm Red Bull, the scheme claims that knocking off early actually improves productivity in the workplace. Red Bull said: “#4pmFinish isnt about slacking off, its about being more productive.Thats why weve surveyed a range of experts – including a scientist, an ex-sports star and a range of successful entrepreneurs – for their tips on clearing your in-tray.”There may be some science behind the publicity stunt, with previous studies showing the benefits of six-hour work days.Staff at Oxford University’s Sleep And Circadian Neuroscience Institute have also carried out research, which seems to support a more relaxed working approach – saying a 9am clock-on is at odds with our internal body clocks and it would be better for staff to begin work at 10am.Anyone who is out-and-about from 2pm to 4pm on a Friday will know that there are a hell of a lot of workers who manage to start the weekend early.Many of those are doing jobs that can be picked up again on Monday.But you can only get away early  that is the culture of your job. Under employment law you are required to carry out the full working day unless otherwise excused by your manager.Britain comes eleventh working 1,143 hours a year. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum blind swimming contact lenses parasite eye
story: Hotel financial controller Emma Jenkins, 39, from Bournemouth, Dorset, was on holiday at a caravan park in Scotland when she took a dip in the on-site pool without removing her lenses.Back at home a week later, she began to suffer from severe pain in her left eye.Emma went to see her GP but just three days later, lost her sight thanks to a microscopic bacteria causing an ulcer which destroyed her cornea.The mother of two said: I had no idea that wearing contact lenses in the pool was so risky. I left them in so I could see.“It’s really frightening how quickly it happened. I was only swimming for about 20 minutes, yet it cost me the sight in one eye.“When I got out of the pool, my left eye was irritated, so I went back to our caravan and took my lenses out, as it was hurting so much.”Over the next few days, Emma suffered headaches and blurred vision, but not wanting to ruin the rest of the holiday for the children, decided to wait until she got home to seek medical help.She was referred to the eye casualty unit at the Royal Bournemouth Hospital later that day where she was diagnosed with anterior uveitis - an inflammation of the middle layer of the eye - and was given steroid drops.I was using the drops, but three days later, I lost the vision in my left eye, as the bacteria had multiplied very quickly.“The blurriness was getting gradually worse and when I woke up on that day and I was in so much pain I couldn’t even open my eye.It really hurt but I was quite calm because I really thought it was going to be fine. I thought it was just a really severe infection.Her partner Dean called a taxi and immediately took her back to eye casualty where she was diagnosed with microbial keratitis and microcystic corneal oedema - meaning she had a swollen and infected cornea which was causing an ulcer to cover her whole iris.Emma was admitted for five days where she received hourly drops to try to save her eye, but it didnt work.The condition had caused full thickness scarring to Emmas left eye, meaning that she could only see movement and light through it.“When I was admitted thought it would get better and get back to normal, she explained.“But, after a few days in hospital I was told by the doctor how serious it was and that the vision would never be back to what it was.“I was shocked, but at the time, I was in too much pain to really take it in.In the following year, Emmas vision deteriorated further.In April 2016, however, she was told that she would be a suitable candidate for a cornea transplant - where the damaged tissue is removed and replaced by healthy tissue from a donor.Emma said: We hoped my eye would heal, but it just kept getting worse. I struggled to live with just one eye and eventually, doctors agreed the cornea transplant was my best option.”After a two month wait, she was taken for her transplant at the centre for sight in East Grinstead, West Sussex, on 1 June 2016.Most opticians advise that contact lense wearers wear swimming goggles for swimming - mainly to reduce the risk of contacts being dislodged.But swimming with contacts can result in eye infections, irritation and potentially sight-threatening conditions such as corneal ulcers .In fact, the FDA has recommended that contacts are not exposed to ANY type of water - including tap water, showers, hot tubs, swimming pools and lakes.If in doubt, take them out before getting wet.Emma was awake during the whole operation and says that the nurse continued to talk to her throughout.The waiting list isn’t very long, as the cornea doesn’t need to be matched like other organs, but it is a very unusual operation, as you are awake throughout and it is done under local anaesthetic.“They numbed my eye and I was told not to move at all. A nurse held my hand, so I could squeeze  I felt pain. I mainly remember just seeing colours and I could only feel the pressure on my eye and sometimes a tiny bit of pain.”It took less than half an hour and Emma was able to leave hospital later that day.She said: As it healed, I started to be able to see more and more. Unfortunately, they weren’t able to remove the full scaring.I can now see more out of that eye but it’s not completely clear. Before it was like looking through a big puffy cloud and now I can see things but they just aren’t perfectly in focus.I suffer from dry eye but it’s worth it to be able to see again.”She added: “My mum, Kim, was amazing throughout everything and helped to care for me while Dean looked after the children. I couldn’t have got through this without my family and friends.“I don’t think people realise the serious dangers of wearing lenses in water. I do still wear a contact lense in one eye but I am much more aware of the dangers.I wear a daily disposable contact lense because I prefer to throwing it away every day. I think everyone just needs to treat them with care.“I’m so grateful for whoever allowed their corneas to be donated as they’ve helped to give me my sight back.”

title: strictly stacey dooley celeb island
story: They have to mask their disappointment, I understand, but the words “Your partner will be . . .  KEVIN!” were no sooner out of the host’s mouth than he was off, pogo dancing round the studio, punching the air and screaming: “YAAAAAAAAAS YES! YEEEEES!”And for what?Stacey Dooley, that’s what. Star of BBC3’s box office smash Stacey Dooley Investigates: Second Chance Sex Offenders and now Stacey Dooley investigates how many people had to Google her name on Sunday morning.She is by no means, though, the most anonymous of the new batch on the 16th series of Strictly, which was quick to remind us of its past triumphs, and equally swt to jog our memories about all the things that remain wrong with this show.Bruno Tonioli is still there, for starters. So’s Tess with those links that all seem to have passed through about ten light-entertainment BBC sub committees, where they’re vetted for any hint of spontaneity.“Swapping the radio studio for the dance studio.”“Swapping the newsroom for the ballroom.”“Ditching the cricket balls for the glitter balls.”Devotees of the show don’t care about these details, of course, and nor do floating viewers  they throw us a single high-profile comedy bone, in the Ed Balls mould, who can transform Strictly Come Dancing into the funniest show on television.Much like last year’s box-ticking frenzy, though, something has gone badly wrong with the booking process again and the class of 2018 has no maverick entertainer, just a lot of people you might vaguely recognise off the telly.Among the slightly more famous contestants there’s dance-trained Pussycat Doll Ashley Roberts, Steps’ Faye Tozer, Lee Ryan out of Blue, Kate “The Silverback” Silverton, from BBC News, cricketer Graeme Swann and Susannah Constantine, who seemed to have got lost on the way to the Loose Women studio and mentioned “the menopause” before she’d even done her Mrs Overall impression in that group dance.Once through that lot, though, you’re into Stacey Dooley territory with Danny John-Jules, a Paralympian, some bloke called Charles off Casualty, who warmed the nation’s heart by referring to himself in the third person, and comedian Seann Walsh, who confirmed: “I’m not here to make anyone laugh.”A statement that should be all over Seann’s Edinburgh Fringe poster every year.The two bookings that irked me most, though, were local radio DJ Vick Hope, whose only recognisable feature is her perfume  and internet vlogger Joe Sugg, whose presence really did flag up TV’s general failure  13million people are logging on to watch this bloke put cling film over his mate’s toilet bowl.It also told me, without much competition from The X Factor, Strictly’s got complacent and rather full of itself.The solution would seem obvious, though. Rip up the flat fee booking system, drop the salaries of the makeweights and spend the excess on a marquee booking like Richard Madeley, Prezza, Eamonn Holmes, Cherie Blair or Farage, who’d empty Britain’s streets with his jive.This is not just my opinion, obviously. Almost everyone who’s looked at this year’s Strictly line-up has concluded it’s not good enough.You can be pretty damn sure then the BBC will take the criticism on board, channel the opinions through a thousand sub-committees and conclude that, yes, unequivocally what this show needs is same sex couples.We live in nutty times.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “JFK: Remembering Jack is a book about which man?”Emma: “Pass.”Bradley Walsh: “2017, The Queen’s Sapphire Jubilee, marked how many years on the throne?”Emma: “100.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which UK Prime Minister starred in the 2003 episode of The Simpsons?”Mikayla: “Winston Churchill.”Bradley Walsh: “In the 1930s, Caroline Mikkelsen became the first woman to set foot in what continent?”Barrie: “Australia.”A CRACKING new series of Celebrity Island with Bear Grylls was immediately transformed into Fantasy Island on Sunday night, thanks to the arrival of Roxanne Pallett, who made an early promise/threat.“If someone gets stung by a jellyfish,” she claimed, earnestly, “I would wee on them.”And  they didn’t get stung? title: princess eugenie wedding bash expense katie glass
story: When 28-year-old Eugenie ties the knot to tequila mogul Jack Brooksbank next month they will do so in front of 250 more guests than her cousin Prince Harry had.The bash will last TWO days and be organised by Peregrine Armstrong-Jones, the man behind Posh and Becks’s bling-tastic nuptials.We are told the party will feature a champagne reception hosted by the Queen.There will be a horse-drawn carriage ride to St George’s Chapel, which will be laden with flowers arranged by Elton John’s florist.There will be a three-course dinner in a marquee laid with a glass dance floor. The first night will culminate in a “festival and funfair”-themed party where 500 guests including Naomi Campbell, George Clooney and Kate Moss will ride dodgems and play on coconut shies as Robbie Williams and Ellie Goulding perform.So far, so OTT.And good for her! If Princess Eugenie wants a Big Fat Royal Wedding, she should have one. Why not get Gypsy Wedding stitcher Thelma Madine to team up with Chanel and make a £50,000, 20st, glow-in-the-dark dress?Why doesn’t Eugenie ride to the church in a giant horse-drawn orb like Katie Price or say her vows on golden Beckham-style thrones?It is beautul Eugenie has found love — she should celebrate however she wants. But where Eugenie’s special day crosses into outrageous is in expecting the public to pay her gigantic security bill.Eugenie’s insistence on being paraded through the streets of Windsor like Marie Antoinette means security is now going to cost us, the taxpayers, an astronomical TWO MILLION POUNDS.Officers on overtime rates will be drafted in, with dozens required to search the procession route in advance.Hard-working Brits who have struggled with eight years of austerity and been exhausted by endless police cuts will bear the brunt of that extra policing so we might catch a glimpse of Eugenie sashaying past in her open-top carriage.Is this what Eugenie meant when she said in a recent interview that she wanted to “share our world” with us?There’s nothing more tasteless than asking other people to pay for your extravagant wedding.Recently a story went viral about a bridezilla called Susan who’d demanded her friends cough up towards her £47,000 bash.Yet Eugenie’s demands make small change of that. As her guests romp on dodgems and get hammered on cocktails, we’ll be hoping we don’t get stabbed or sprayed with acid on the way to the shops because there probably won’t be many cops to help us.Extreme? Maybe not when we hear — as we did last month — that a third of bobbies on the beat have been axed in the past three years, while crime has shot up.Some fed-up villagers have even started paying for their own security firms.You hear that, Eugenie? Paying for their own security!Indeed, we might ask why Eugenie’s dad, Prince Andrew, worth some £65million, isn’t dipping into his reservoir of cash to pay the security bill?It is he who is apparently so keen for Eugenie to make a carriage-drawn arrival at church. Just as Andrew was adamant his daughters should retain Princess status in the face of Prince Charles’ worthy attempts to slim down the monarchy.Perhaps Eugenie’s groom Jack Brooksbank — the great-grandson of Sir John Spencer Coke, the son of the 2nd Earl of Leicester — might stump up some cash?Or Eugenie herself could contribute? Even  it might mean troubling her £3.6million trust funds or taking one fewer holiday this year?In an interview with Vogue Eugenie spoke with her sister Beatrice about wanting to be seen as “real”.Yet in some ways, “real” is exactly what Eugenie is. A marginal royal, she has no official royal .She is not responsible for carrying out any royal engagements or public duties. For us, then, she does nothing.For Prince Harry, it made sense to indulge in a whistles-and-bells Royal Wedding .People like Harry, you see. Harry performs royal duties . He has served in the Forces and established the Invictus Games. An psos Mori poll this year had him and his gran — aka the Queen — as the world’s most favourite royals. For us Brits he was the favourite.But we can’t and shouldn’t roll out the platinum carpet for every minor royal who ties the knot. To do so makes a mockery of the royals’ claims they want to modernise.It reinforces the dated and offensive notion that the aristocracy are born to deserve better than us.In that Vogue interview Eugenie spoke about how she wanted her wedding to be plastic-free. How very woke.I just wish this supposedly modern royal was as conscious of social inequality as she is of the environmentOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Imagine how it will soar once our exit is done and dusted.Wages are growing at their fastest in three years, and above inflation. Unemployment is at a 40-year low.Youth unemployment has NEVER been so low.Growth has ticked up to 0.6 per cent.There is a record number of vacancies.With EU migration down and jobs galore being created, the competition for workers is pushing up pay. And, though we DO meet Nato’s spending target, ours has declined steadily.Defence chief Sir Nick Carter has rightly warned “our ability to pre-empt or respond to threats will be eroded  we don’t keep up with our adversaries”.France has finally committed to raise its defence spending.We must too . . .And convince Donald Trump that a strong, united Nato is vital for global security.THE Help To Buy scheme is a vastly expensive and flawed sticking-plaster to the housing crisis. Its future must be reviewed.Some £8billion of public money has been splurged on George Osborne’s idea to give first-time buyers interest-free loans to buy a brand-new property.And while it HAS helped many, they have often paid over the odds and will be stuck with a home which they can’t sell or is in negative equity  prices dip.Meanwhile, Help To Buy has made fortunes for building giants and their lavishly paid bosses. They have built more houses, but not nearly enough for the extra demand the scheme created.The REAL solution is for the Government to free up land and relax planning rules to get hundreds of thousands more homes built for our booming population.That, and that alone, will help make them genuinely more affordable and get a generation on to the property ladder.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: wetherspoons jagermeister hennessy courvoisier brandy brexit
story: The huge chain is axing French brandies as well as the German Jagermeister and replacing them with non-EU alternatives.Boss Tim Martin, a passionate Brexit campaigner, said he wants to show the sunlit uplands that await Britain once weve quit the EU.Wetherspoon has already announced it wont sell Champagne and prosecco in future.Today the company added three more drinks to the list of those expelled from its pubs.Jagermeister, commonly mixed with energy drinks to form a Jagerbomb, is being replaced by English herbal liqueur Strika.Courvoisier and Hennessy, two of the most popular types of brandy, will be supplanted by E&ampJ Brandy from the US and Australian brand Black Bottle.The firm says the switch will lead to lower prices for drinkers.Mr Martin said today: The three new products will be offered at a lower price than those they are replacing.This is a signicant move by us and highlights our commitment to offering an excellent range of UK and world products, with the emphasis on quality and value for the two million customers who visit our pubs each week.In blind tastings conducted by Wetherspoon, the new products were more popular than those they are replacing.Many commentators talk of a clf-edge  the UK crashes out of the EU without a deal.In reality, there is no clf-edge, only sunlit uplands beyond the EUs protectionist system of quotas and tarfs.All EU products have UK or non-EU replacements, often at equal or better quality and price.

title: norovirus exeter schools vomiting bug
story: Parents claimed ill students were even forced to carry sick buckets, vomiting as they left Westclyst and Broadclyst Primary Schools in Devon.Public Health England has been called in to help manage the outbreak, confirming 60 students and staff were affected by the bug.One parent told The Mirror it was like something from a horror film as the highly contagious outbreak spread.Speaking to the Sun Online, Broadclyst Community Primary School headteacher Jonathan Bishop confirmed about 45 out of about 500 children were off yesterday after falling ill with Norovirus, while about five Westclyst students out of 105 were off.He said: We are having extra deep cleans during the day and at the end of the day, which includes things like cleaning door handles.The school nurse is also going into classes telling children about the importance of handwashing.He said a parents information night scheduled for Wednesday was also cancelled to manage the outbreak.The schools, while separate, sit on the same site.Mr Bishop said: It has been very fast-paced, it came on yesterday morning and by the end of the day we had 45 children off sick.Norovirus is one of the most common stomach bugs in the UK and is also referred to as “the winter vomiting bug”, although it can affect people all year round.According to the NHS website, you are likely to have caught norovirus  you experience a sudden sick feeling, projectile vomiting and watery diarrhoea.Other symptoms can include a slight fever, headaches, painful cramps and aching limbs.Luckily, the symptoms generally only last for about two to three days.If you think you have contracted it contact NHS direct but stay at home, as you won’t be offered any treatment at hospital and you could put others at risk by being there.You can ease the symptoms by doing a few things:We are following all the right steps.He said there were no plans to close the school.Nick Young, Consultant in Health Protection for Public Health England South West, said: We are currently working with the schools to reduce the risk of ongoing infection from likely norovirus infection.”Norovirus infection leads to diarrhoea, vomiting and abdominal or stomach cramps that people tend to recover from quickly. If affected, it is important to drink plenty of water to avoid dehydration.To reduce the risk to others, stay off nursery, school or work, avoid preparing food and minimise direct contact with others until 48 hours after your symptoms have stopped.Mr Young said outbreaks could be dficult to control as it could be easily transmitted.He said: The most effective way to respond to an outbreak is to clean and disinfect contaminated areas very thoroughly and to institute good hygiene measures including hand-washing.The school have taken these measures and issued advice to children, parents and staff.”

title: google maps couple beach kissing
story: The love birds were snapped gazing into each others eyes, while sitting on towels in the blaring sunshine.The woman donning a pair of sunglasses and a grey t-shirt, tilts her head as she appears to be moving in for a smooch.Her partner appears equally as keen, but is somehow missing his right limbs and torso.Their positioning looks so twisted, it almost looks painful.As the user tried to zoom out of the bizarre image, a pair of legs without a body can be seen beside them.Google Street View snaps pics of dferent places using a mix of high-tech cameras strapped to an assortment of vehicles and user-uploaded photos.These images are then stitched together to make a 360-degree model of the world that users can click and drag to explore.But sometimes these panoramic views can go a bit haywire when pieced together.It comes after another Google Maps image showed a three-legged girl walking through an alleyway.The image of the girl walking with a friend in Split, Croatia, completely baffled Reddit users.Dozens of users branded her mutant girl as they tried to speculate what had caused the glitch.

title: hurricane florence tracker path us east coast
story: Heres how you can track the storms movements and how it has affected those in its path.In the US the main body that tracks storms such as hurricanes is the federal agency the National Weather Service.It was founded in February 1870 and based in Maryland.The NWS had a budget of 1.124billion in 2016.However, within that body, there is the specialist National Hurricane Center which was founded in 1965 specically tasked with monitoring weather systems within the tropics.The NHC was established to watch and track the formation of “hazardous tropical weather” and to issue warnings in a bid to reduce the impact of the storms in order to save lives and help reduce the financial cost of damage caused by a storm.The centre uses satellite images as well as radar and aircraft reconnaissance to track and monitor storms.The NHC has a specialist team, the 53rd Weather Reconnaissance Squadron, known as the Hurricane Hunters, part of the Air Force Reserve, which flies into tropical storms and hurricanes to collect scientic data.On September 14 the storm weakened to a Category 1 storm - but the threat to le along the Carolina coast remained signicant.The National Weather Service said it expected between 20 and 40 inches of rainfall to fall in some regions.Over 100,000 in North Carolina had lost power on Friday morning with over 125 shelters currently in operation as thousands were forced out of their homes.Seawater was pictured rolling down the streets of North Carolina as authorities warned surviving the storm would be a test of endurance, teamwork, common sense and patience.Looking ahead to Saturday the National Hurricane Center said: Little change in strength is expected before the eye of Florence reaches the coast, with slow weakening expected after the centre moves inland or meanders near the coast.More signicant weakening is forecast on Saturday as Florence moves farther inland over central South Carolina. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
