story: NewsMeet Mrs Hinch - the 'cleaning mad' woman from Essex whose tips are sweeping nation and 'changing lives'Sophie Hinchclfe - known as Mrs Hinch - has gained a 'Hinch Army' of followers who follow her cleaning tips religiouslyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByHannah KaneAmber Hicks09:45, 13 SEP 2018Updated07:06, 14 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/meet-mrs-hinch-whose-cleaning-13237956,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA 'cleaning mad' woman whose routine is sweeping the nation has gained an army of fans who cannot wait to get their feather dusters and rubber gloves out. Sophie Hinchclfe - known as Mrs Hinch - had no idea her tips would prove so popular and gain her hundreds and thousands of followers around the world. She has now sparked a frenzy of people stockpiling cleaning products to make their homes spotless - with some items selling out and going on eBay for triple the price. If you step inside Sophie's Essex house you will find immaculately clean floors, skirtings and worktops decorated in cool grey tones, reports Essex Live .  The 28-year-old hairdresser created her profile @MrsHinchHome_X_ in March when her now husband Jamie began to decorate the Maldon home they bought two years ago. However, it has only been since July that the number of followers sky rocketed when she started sharing her cleaning routines, and now she has more than 265,000 followers. It just spiralled and I couldn't be more grateful, she said. It started off as around 200 or 500 [followers] a month and now it's as many as 35,000 a day. It's in the last four to six weeks that it has gone viral. I've got followers from Ireland, the US and Australia and they are all amazing.  Her dedicated following have started calling themselves 'Hinch Army', using #HinchArmy to share their own successes using some of Sophie's methods and recommended products. She believes that the success of the page is down to her being true to herself and sharing her love for having fun when cleaning. Sophie said: It's been overwhelming but amazing. People are sharing before and after photos of their homes and I'm just so pleased my account has helped so many people together. I don't bombard cleaning on my grid page. It's mainly on my stories and my page then shows the results of fun cleaning, aka Hinching.  I name all my cloths and cleaning equipment, which may sound odd to some, but it is a laugh for us all and now everyone is getting involved. It's unbelievable. I'm a worrier and I struggle with anxiety, she added. For me, to keep my mind off of what was worrying me would be to clean and organise something and love the end result. It took my mind off worrying. It helps me control my panic attacks too. Since I've started the account others have messaged me saying I've changed their lives and helped them with their mental health which to me is simply amazing. I get thousands of messages each day like this.  Sophie has even got her husband involved in her antics. Jamie is so supportive, she said. He is amazing. He gets involved too and I ask him to try and 'Hinch' the sinks. Everyone loves Mr Hinch and watching him too. Sophie shares the products she uses and what is in her cleaning 'baskets' and wants people to know that she does not clean all the time. Everyone seems to have caught the 'Hinch' bug, she said. They are wanting to try the products I love and it's great to see the army itself helping each other, complimenting each other and sharing tips.  But I don't clean constantly every day. As long as I clean for around 30 minutes or an hour each day I feel OK. I like to clean as and when something needs to be done. I clean for fun. My thing is the kitchen sink. The Hinch Army loves a shiny sink. She also maintains that you do not need to spend a fortune for sparkling results. I have many cleaning baskets, Sophie said. Consisting of a weekly basket and a daily one. I would say that organising my cleaning products is the biggest thing that I enjoy.  We all like to have our products in the right basket. I'm also pine mad so I have to have pine products.  I shop in Poundstretcher and Poundland and B&ampM for my items. I use things because they are cheap but they work well. I don't always go for the really expensive products. Now I've shown my followers what I like to buy, I go into the shops and struggle to find my favourites as the shelves have been Hinch hauled. But it's so funny to see. Sophie is not planning on slowing down any time soon. Her account is now the second most influential home interior account on Instagram in the UK and she is excited to see where this could lead to.

title: mum who shed 20 stone
story: NewsMum who shed 20 stone kills herself after new slim figure made her depression even worseKelly Burndred went from 20 stone to just 10.5 stone, but her new slim figure did not bring her the happiness she had "craved" and she felt like there was "nowhere else to turn"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitchingHayley Parker06:57, 14 SEP 2018Updated08:39, 14 SEP 2018NewsKelly Burndred with her husband Gareth and daughter Jess "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum who shed 20 stone to get the body she always wanted took her own le because being thin made her depression even worse, her devastated husband says.  Kelly Burndred went from 20 stone to just 10.5 stone, but her new slim figure did not bring her the happiness she had craved and she felt like there was nowhere else to turn. The 37-year-old became a dferent person plagued by even darker thoughts as the pounds dropped off following a gastric bypass in 2015.  Kelly's husband Gareth set up a support group in her name after she hanged herself, and has now warned how losing weight cannot solve depression, Stoke-on-Trent Live reports.   The mum-of-one's fixation with her size, which started as a young girl, was a symptom of her own internal struggle with her mental health. After two unsuccessful suicide attempts, Kelly took her own le in April this year. Gareth, 37, from Chesterton, Staffordshire, said: “Kelly had suffered most of her le. On the outside, she was very bubbly and confident and had loads of friends. But inside, she was struggling. “After our daughter was born she had crippling post-natal depression but she overcame it, or so we thought.  “We hoped, after the gastric bypass, that Kelly would find the happiness she craved. But her depression got much worse. She had blamed all her problems, all her le, on her weight. So when she became thin, and she wasn’t happy, she felt like there was nowhere else to turn. “I want to stress how important it is to speak out. I just hope that Kelly’s story, and the support group, will help to save another le.” Gareth and Kelly met on New Year’s Eve 2001 in a nightclub.  He said: “We were two opposites, and yet we just clicked. I was quiet and shy, and Kelly was loud, bubbly and chatty. “As I got to know her better, I realised that Kelly’s confidence was just a front. Deep down, she was very insecure and unhappy with the way she looked.” Two years on, they had a daughter, Jess, now aged 14. Gareth said: “Kelly had been told she would never be able to have children because she had polycystic oies so when she fell pregnant it was a huge surprise. We couldn’t wait for our baby to arrive.  “Kelly loved being a mum, but she showed signs straightaway of post-natal depression. She didn’t want to leave the house and she became very withdrawn and anxious. “She wouldn’t put Jess to bed because she was afraid something might happen to her during the night. I put Jess to bed every night. She didn’t trust herself as a mum and it was hard. “I tried to support Kelly, but I felt she was pushing me away. Our relationship suffered and we went through a really bad patch. “But in time, the depression eased and we became closer again.” And in 2008, Kelly proposed.  Gareth said: “Kelly was around a size 26 when we got married, but to me, she looked stunning. I know she was unhappy with her weight, but it just didn’t matter to me. “She had been bullied all through school because of her weight. It had always been a problem for her. She got down to a size 16 after one diet but it all crept back on.” In 2010, Kelly was awarded a forensic science degree at university. Gareth said: “I was really proud of her. She got a job at the council and she had loads of mates, she was really popular.” By 2014, Kelly’s weight had hit 30 stone. She was referred for gastric bypass surgery in March 2015.  Gareth said: “The surgery was a big step and it was a worry, but I knew how desperate she was. I just hoped this would help to make her happy.” Kelly seemed to cope well with the surgery and her weight dropped to just over ten stones. But her hair fell out, which was a recognised side effect. Gareth said: “She had a weave done, to cover up her bald patches. When I collected her from the salon she looked so young and beautul and I told her how much I loved her. I will always remember that moment.” But following the surgery, Kelly’s character changed. Gareth said: “After the weight loss, Kelly changed mentally as well as physically. I really felt as though she was two people and I knew she felt the same.  “She would say: ‘I know I should be happy now, but I’m not.’ She was scared of reaching her goal weight because she didn’t want the journey to end. “Now she had got what she wanted, she didn’t want it. All her le, she had blamed everything on her weight, and now she was thin and she realised her problems were still there. “Her depression became much worse.” Kelly also struggled with excess skin left by her weight loss. Gareth said: “She was very self-conscious about her excess skin and she refused to let me see her naked. She asked for surgery but the GP couldn’t help.” Eight months ago, Gareth was woken during the night to find Kelly running a bath and carrying an extension lead into the bathroom. She admitted she was planning to kill herself.  He said: “I was panic stricken. I began keeping an eye on her and we asked for a mental health appointment, but there was a two-month wait which was incredibly frustrating. “I began keeping a close eye on her. But another night, whilst I was sleeping, she slipped out of the house. I had to call the police and they found her, not far away. She admitted she had been planning to jump from a bridge. I was out of my mind with worry. “Kelly’s parents, Bryan and Doreen, kindly offered to pay for a private consultation and in April she finally saw a consultant. She was prescribed medication and I finally felt a sense of relief. I really felt she was making progress. “Two days later, there was a TV programme about a Hollywood star’s suicide. “Kelly made a point of us watching it together. Looking back, I wonder  this was a warning sign. I wonder  it is something I could have picked up on. “The next night, Jess was staying over with her grandparents. Kelly and I watched a film, and we had a couple of glasses of wine and afterwards, we made love. It was a really special evening.  “Again, looking back, I wonder  she had planned this – knowing what was coming next. I just don’t know. “Late that night, we lay in bed in each other’s arms, and Kelly said she couldn’t sleep and she wanted to go downstairs. I made her promise to come back to bed in an hour. I didn’t want her up all night, worrying. “I could hear her downstairs, I thought maybe she was on the phone, and eventually, I drted off to sleep.” Gareth woke early the following morning for work, and Kelly’s side of the bed was empty. He said: “I just thought she had slept downstairs. I went to find her and I saw her, lying on the floor, behind our French doors. But I still thought she was asleep. “I went over to her and said her name. But, as I touched her leg, it was stone cold and I panicked. I was pleading with her to wake up. “I grabbed my phone to call an ambulance. I felt certain the paramedics would save her.” Kelly could not be saved and she was pronounced dead that morning aged just 37.

story: NewsNew super 'yellow vulture' speed cameras can catch drivers including those eating behind the wheelThe cameras face oncoming traffic and can do a lot more than catch those driving over the speed limitShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitchingMiles O'Leary08:46, 13 SEP 2018Updated09:44, 14 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/what-penalties-speeding-uk-13105413,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNew super 'yellow vulture' speed cameras that can catch drivers who are using their phone or eating behind the wheel have arrived in the UK. The cameras feature new LED infrared equipment and they look nothing like the traditional ones that drivers are used to seeing at the roadside. They face oncoming traffic and some motorists may not realise they are cameras at all. In addition to speeding, the equipment can catch drivers who aren't wearing a seatbelt or are using their phone, eating, drinking or smoking when they're meant to be concentrating on the road, Devon Live reports.  The technology, part of the new Safety Camera Partnership, is meant to snare speeding drivers more effectively. A cluster of cameras has been set up along Gdynia Way, which leads into into Plymouth city centre in Devon. The cameras face oncoming traffic, while an accompanying LED box system is positioned 20 yards before them. How do average speed cameras work?  The multiple cameras  are set at separate locations along a stretch of road  and are synchronised to record the exact time that each car passes using number plate reading technology. Then a computer will work out the average speed between the cameras to determine  the car was over the speed limit. Some people wrongly think that each camera records a driver's speed as they pass each camera before the computer works out the average speed as the car passed every camera - this explains why some drivers think they can speed up between the cameras and slow down as they pass them. But doing this is likely to land you with a fine - the cameras simply record the time you pass them and the computer works out how long it has taken you to pass the distance between them. Do the cameras work at night?  Yes. They are fitted with infra red illuminators to ensure they work night and day, and all weathers. Can the cameras run out of film? No. Unlike some other speed cameras, average speed camera information is saved to a computer. Can the cameras catch motorbikes? Yes. The cameras are equipped to capture all types of vehicles. If a vehicle changes lanes will they avoid any fines? No. The cameras calculate for lane changes. But this myth can mean people dangerously switch lanes increasing the chance of crashes.

story: NewsRetired wartime nurse aged 105 says secret to long le is to 'avoid men as they're not worth the hassle'When asked for tips to live longer, Brenda Osborne said that men 'aren't worth the hassle'Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByHana Carter20:56, 13 SEP 2018Updated23:10, 13 SEP 2018NewsThe 105 singleton worked as a nurse through both world wars "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA 105-year-old woman who lived through both World Wars says her secret to longevity was to stay single. Brenda Osborne, born in Mansfield, Nottingham, in 1913, shared her tips with carers at her retirement home during her 105 birthday party. She told them that she got to her old age by steering clear of men, working hard and getting out in the fresh air. Brenda, who was born the same year as the first ever Chelsea Flower Show even received an award for having one day off sick in 33 years as a nurse. The centenarian lived in her childhood home for a staggering 93 years before moving into the nursing home last year - just after her 104 birthday. She shared the modest two bedroom property with her two sisters, Vera and Beryl and nephew Ian before they passed away. Speaking of her longevity, determined Brenda said: I would put my good health down to hard work and avoiding men.  I loved celebrating my birthday although I was disappointed the Queen didn't come. I received my letter from her but I thought an appearance was the least she could do. Brenda was educated at Carter Lane School and Queen Elizabeth’s Grammar School and in her younger years loved to go to her caravan at Ingoldmells. She first started work at Victoria Hospital in 1940, nursing Dunkirk veterans. She became an assistant nurse in 1946 and then a senior nurse 1953. Brenda now resides at Brookholme Croft Nursing Home in Hasland and marked the milestone birthday with a party. Speaking of Brenda’s big day, her great-niece Marie Pollard said: “It was a lovely day for Brenda to celebrate with all her nearest and dearest.

Britain has accused two Russians, Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov , of carrying out the poisoning of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia. Today, in an interview on the Russian state-funded RT news channel , they claimed to be victims of a fantastical coincidence.   Mere hours after their interview, a TripAdvisor account was created using Boshirov's name.   It features an image taken from the Russian's appearance on TV as the profile picture. A TripAdvisor reviewer named Mark R also decided to join in on the controversial joke, writing: Me and my co-assassin, sorry, 'tourist' went there because the big man  needed a loose end sorting out, sorry - photo's of the spire for his photo-collection of massive erections.

She is currently one of a glut of tropical storms in the Atlantic, with Florence sparking mass evacuations as she heads towards landfall in the US states of North Carolina, South Carolina and Virginia. But the Met Office says Helene could be heading east towards the south-western corners of the UK, with the tip of Ireland among the worst affected. A similar section of Wales and the Cornish peninsular are also expected to bear the brunt of any storm-like weather, although much of the rest of England could be noticeably windier by the time Helene hits land on Tuesday morning.  Emma Smith, meteorologist with the Exeter-based Met Office, said more details would emerge within the next day over what impact the storm might have. She said: Helene is moving up from the Atlantic towards us. Hurricane Joyce is also in the Atlantic so we need to see how those two systems are going to move around each other because that could have an impact. It looks like Helene will move towards Ireland on Tuesday morning. It's possible that the west coast of Wales and Cornwall could get some winds as well, but we will get a clearer picture of what to expect very soon.

story: NewsWoman admits sending photo of her performing sex act on new man to ex-boyfriend who then murdered himSarah Bramley, 29, pleaded guilty on the basis of incitement to cause common assault, claiming she did not intend her former partner David Saunders to stab Michael Lawson to deathShare&nbspByJeremy ArmstrongLucy Clarke-Billings17:27, 13 SEP 2018Updated21:29, 13 SEP 2018NewsSarah Bramley admitted sending the photo which killer David Saunders said tipped him over the edge "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman has admitted sending an intimate picture to her ex-boyfriend who then murdered the man in the image out of jealousy. Sarah Bramley, 29, pleaded guilty at Teesside Crown Court on Thursday to encouraging or assisting the commission of an offence. The defendant, of Darlington, Co Durham, sent former partner David Saunders, 33, a picture of her performing a sex act on her new lover, 34-year-old Michael Lawson. It is understood that Bramley sent the image believing her ex-partner would carry out a common assault, rather than a murder. But in the early hours of July 1 last year, shortly after receiving the photo, Saunders stabbed father-of-one Mr Lawson through the heart.  In December, Saunders was jailed for le at Teesside Crown Court with a minimum term of 22 and a half years, after he admitted murdering Mr Lawson. At the time, Judge Stephen Ashurst told the murderer: Jealousy was very much at the heart of your behaviour. Ultimately a le was needlessly lost because of a loss of control. Bramley was granted bail and will be sentenced at the same court in October.  A court heard Saunders was tipped over the edge by the explicit image. As he issued threats against Sarah and Michael Lawson, she goaded him by texting: He is twice your size, maybe Davey Saunders might actually get a bat, his trial heard last year. From the witness box Saunders told of his anger at being sent the explicit photograph.  He forwarded it to his friend Claire Richards and said: I was upset, really upset and angry. I loved her, it was not nice to see that. I felt angry. Judge Stephen Ashurst ruled that Miss Bramley's action had a very important bearing on Saunders' actions. But she was not at the trial last year, having travelled to Australia soon after the killing, with the full knowledge of the police. She was held after re-entering the UK earlier this year and yesterday appeared at Teesside Crown Court charged with inciting an assault. She pleaded guilty on the basis that she did not intend Saunders to commit murder and that she only anticipated there may be a minor assault.  Robert Newcombe, for Bramley, said: My client has indicated that she pleads guilty on the basis of incitement to cause common assault. Judge Ashurst asked prosecutor Nick Dry: This is notwithstanding the fact she knew Saunders had a reputation for violence and that he carried weapons? Mr Dry answered: We have come to conclusion that she did not intend to happen what in fact did happen. Bramley, dressed in black top and black jeans, faces a sentence of up to six months in prison. In December last year, as he sentenced car dealer Saunders, Judge Ashurst rejected Saunders' defence that he did not intend to kill Michael. The court heard he carried a kitchen kne that he used to deliver a single fatal blow to the heart in the early hours of July 1 in Darlington.  During the hearing, the court heard that after performing the sex act on Michael and sending the photograph of it to Saunders, Sarah then slapped her lover and ordered him to leave the house. She is alleged to have texted Saunders saying: I have just smashed the lad clean in the face because he wouldn't go home. What have I got myself involved with? The court was told that she added: He is outside the house, feel free to smack the c***. Saunders admitted murder but sought to lower the minimum term he must serve by claiming he did not carry the kne to the scene and did not intend to kill Michael.

story: NewsYoung mum nearly BALD after 'women scratch her eyeballs and tear out hair' in sickening nightclub attackHollie-Louise Brown, 23, feared she would never see her kids again - and can barely look at herself in the mirror without crying anymoreShare&nbspByHannah Smith09:07, 13 SEP 2018Updated12:07, 13 SEP 2018NewsHollie-Louise  cannot stop sobbing every time she looks in the mirror "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young mum feared she would never see her kids again after a group of women allegedly scratched her eyeballs and tore her hair out in a nightclub attack. Hollie-Louise Brown has shared photos of her horric injuries and admits she can barely look at herself in the mirror anymore. The 23-year-old says she thought she was going to die in the attack while out for a drink in Northumberland on Saturday night. She claims she was left unconscious on the nightclub floor. Her attackers allegedly scratched at her eyeballs and kicked her in the head, while she could 'hear the hair tearing from her scalp'.  The telesales worker was left half bald and covered in cuts, bruises and cigarette burns. She feared she would not 'make it home to her children' during her 25-minute ordeal and later needed a CT scan to check for brain damage. Kind-hearted pals launched a fundraising page to help raise cash for hair treatment which has now raised &pound1,250 - almost three times its initial target. Hollie-Louise, from Choppington, Northumberland, said: I'm still in a lot of shock. I just can't stop sobbing every time I walk past the mirror. I'm absolutely heartbroken at the state of myself. The attack was unprovoked and there was no reason for it. I didn't think it was ever going to stop. I could hear my hair being ripped out.  I wondered  I was going to make it home to my children or  I'd even get to see them again. Hollie-Louise had been to Bubbles pub in Ashington, Northumberland, on Saturday night when she was allegedly attacked at around 1am. The single mum claims the incident started when a woman began dancing around her and 'bumping' into her. When Hollie-Louise confronted her, the woman allegedly leaped on her - while her friends tore at her hair. After falling to the floor, Hollie-Louise claims she was strangled and kicked to the head and body in a sustained attack that lasted around 25 minutes. Meanwhile, other women allegedly scratched at her eyes after someone shouted 'gouge out her eyes' from the sideline. Hollie-Louise claimed: She was bouncing around the dance floor and bumping into me on purpose. I asked her what she was doing and she pushed me.  I grabbed her and then all her friends began pulling at my hair and kicking me. We were rolling around the floor and they were all pulling at my hair. One of them was strangling me... I'm almost bald now. By the time the attack had ended I didn't really know what was going on. One put my fingers in her mouth and was trying to bite. I was kicked in the head repeatedly. She added: My eyelashes are gone because of where they tried to scratch my eyeballs. It went on for ages - it was probably about 25 minutes. According to my friends I ended up unconscious on the floor.  After coming round, Hollie-Louise rushed home to her two sons, admitting she feared she'd never see them again. Her dad helped her report it to the police and the next day she attended hospital and saw the police forensics team, who she claims confirmed that a cigarette had been deliberately put out on her. During the days following the incident, the mum's bruises reportedly worsened and she now fears the women will . Hollie-Louise said: I went straight home because my dad was babysitting at my house and I needed to get back to my children. When I got in at around 1.45am, they were both awake when I got in and my oldest is only three, but he looked at me in shock because I looked so dferent. Obviously I was really upset and my hair had been pulled out.  I went to the forensic team at the police station. They confirmed they'd put a cigarette out on me and I had scratches and bruises all over my body. My injuries have actually got worse since then because the bruising has come out. I went and had a CT scan because I'd been kicked in the head. Luckily they said there was no permanent damage and it's just bruised. I've also been given antibiotics because of the cigarette burns. Northumbria Police confirmed three women in their 20s had been arrested in connection with the attack but released 'under investigation'. A spokesperson from Northumbria Police said: “In the early hours of Sunday  police received a report of an assault at Bubbles night club on John Street in Ashington.

story: NewsHurricane Florence: New Bern residents trapped by 10ft flood climb onto roofs as 'bodies float in water'Families trapped in or on top of their homes have posted urgent pleas on social media as rescue teams go from home to home in a race against time and rising floodwatersShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitching10:09, 14 SEP 2018Updated10:25, 14 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/waters-rise-terrying-levels-new-13242553,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Hurricane Florence rescuers are desperately trying to reach dozens of people trapped on roofs or in attics by a catastrophic 10ft flood that has submerged homes.  Families who are stuck in their homes - or their loved ones - have posted urgent pleas on social media as teams in boats go from home to home in a race against time and rising floodwaters. There were unconfirmed claims on social media that bodies were seen floating in the water in New Bern, North Carolina, after a storm surge overwhelmed the coastal city. One desperate resident tweeted: If anybody could help... our cars is under water and so is our house stuck in attic. Phone about to die please send help.  About 200 residents - who either decided to stay put despite an evacuation order or were unable to leave - have been rescued and about 150 more were still waiting as water levels continued to rise in the early hours of Friday. The water rescue mission was launched as Category 1 Florence walloped the region with huge waves, torrential rain and powerful winds. Unveried video said to have been shot in New Bern showed water up to the second storey of one residence as waves crashed against the outer wall.         Local residents told how people were forced to climb onto their roofs or into their attics because the water was so high. Those who were trapped on their roofs were in the dark and being battered by heavy rain and fierce winds as they waited to be rescued by boat with phone batteries that were dead or almost out of power. People whose loved ones were trapped - including elderly parents and residents with young children - pleaded for help on social media.    One Twitter user wrote: My sister and her familly are trapped! please send help! People in Sunnyside are in their attics waiting to be rescued . Local officials were overwhelmed by calls from people who were stranded, as rescuers went out into the storm and put their lives on the line to save those who didn't heed earlier warnings to get out of the storm's way. Seventeen people were stranded on one street alone in Fairfield Harbor in New Bern. The City of New Bern wrote on Twitter: Currently ~150 awaiting rescue in New Bern. We have 2 out-of-state FEMA teams here for swt water rescue.  More are on the way to help us. WE ARE COMING TO GET YOU. You may need to move up to the second story, or to your attic, but WE ARE COMING TO GET YOU. Emergency officials in Craven County, which includes New Bern, told CNN that it has received more than 100 calls for help from people stuck on the roofs of their homes and cars. Locals residents and volunteers joined the rescue, asking people who were trapped or whose loved ones were trapped to call them or message them on social media and tell them where to go. Staff at a local TV news channel, WCTI, were forced to flee the station in New Bern when it began taking on water.  Two meteorologists - Donnie Cox and Shane Hinton - were the last two in the building and they stayed on the air to keep viewers up to date until it was no longer safe. They signed off and the live broadcast came to an end, with the channel showing weather radar until a sister station in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, picked up the feed. Presenter Jaime McCutcheon tweeted: So that really did just happen. The water started rising and we evacuated almost an entire TV station in about 15 minutes. The National Weather Service tweeted: Catastrophic storm surge across New Bern is prompting water rescues from #Florence.

story: NewsHurricane Florence tracker: Path updates as storm hits coast sparking major floods and multiple tornado warningWe map out where Florence, which has weakened slightly to a Category 1 storm, will strike like "a Mike Tyson punch to the Carolina coast"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill04:40, 14 SEP 2018Updated04:44, 14 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/us-news/video/incredible-time-lapse-shows-hurricane-13241841,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHeavy rain, gusting winds and rising floodwaters from Hurricane Florence deluged the Carolinas on Thursday as the monster storm prepared to move inland. The slow-moving storm crept toward the coastline, threatening millions of people in its path with record rainfall and punishing surf. Hurricane Florence weakened to a Category 1 storm late on Thursday night with little change in strength expected before it moves inland on Friday. Florence is about 60 miles  east-southeast of Wilmington, North Carolina with maximum sustained winds of 90 mph , the Miami-based weather forecaster said.  The storm remained huge, unpredictable and potentially deadly ahead of its forecast landfall near Cape Fear, North Carolina, at mid-day on Friday. The centre of the storm is expected to hit North Carolina's southern coast Friday, then drt southwest before moving inland on Saturday. According to the National Hurricane Centre, this will allow enough time for almost 40 inches of rain to fall in some places.  North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper told a news conference that the historic hurricane would unleash rains and floods that would inundate almost the entire state in several feet of water. The sheer size of the storm meant it could batter the U.S. East Coast with hurricane-force winds for nearly a full day, according to weather forecasters. An estimated 10 million people live in the storm's path, according to the US Weather Prediction Center, and coastal businesses and homes were boarded up in anticipation this week. More than one million people were ordered to evacuate the coasts of the Carolinas and Virginia and thousands moved to emergency shelters.  Florence's maximum sustained winds were clocked today at 105mph after it was downgraded to a Category 2 on the five-step Saffir-Simpson scale, according to the NHC. The winds had been as high as 140mph earlier in the week. Jeff Byard of the Federal Emergency Management Agency  warned residents the storm would bring a Mike Tyson punch to the Carolina coast. Heed the warnings, Byard said.  Thursday The storm's centre was about 108 miles  east of Wilmington, North Carolina, at 3pm EDT but already some 19,000 homes and businesses were without power by mid-afternoon in the Carolinas and Virginia. Millions of people are expected to lose power from the storm and restoration could take weeks. The National Hurricane Centre also said the threat of tornadoes was increasing as Florence neared shore and South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster said the heavy rains could trigger landslides in the western part of his state. Florence could bring wind-driven storm surges of seawater as high as 13 feet  and NHC Director Ken Graham said on Facebook they could push in as far as 2 miles .  Thursday 8pm Florence is expected to remain off the coast for the next few days, churning the coast with storm surge, high winds and flooding rainfall. Heavy rains were forecast to extend into the Appalachian Mountains, affecting parts of Alabama, Tennessee, Kentucky and West Virginia. Emergency declarations were in force in Georgia, South andNorth Carolina, Virginia, Maryland and the District of Columbia. Near the beach in Wilmington, a Waffle House restaurant, part of a chain with a reputation for staying open during disasters, had no plans to = close, even  power is lost.  Friday 4am Florence has weakened to a Category 1 storm, with little change in strength expected before it moves inland later on Friday. Florence is about 60 miles  east-southeast of Wilmington, North Carolina with maximum sustained winds of 90 mph , the Miami-based weather forecaster said. More signicant weakening was expected over the weekend and into early next week while Florence moves inland, the NHC said. Le-threatening storm surges and hurricane-force winds are occurring along the North Carolina coast, with the threat of freshwater flooding seen increasing over the next several days, it added.  Friday 8am By Friday morning, the storm's wind speed is estimated to be around 100mph as the hurricane remains off the North Carolina coast. The storm, which is expected to be Category 2 by this time, will then start to drt left down the coast. It is unclear when or  it will make landfall. Some reports suggest it will remain in the ocean gathering strength by this stage.   Friday 11pm It's believed the storm will hover off the coast before making landfall. It's unusual for a hurricane to linger along a coastline and this could bring dire results as parts of the Carolinas could endure hurricane conditions for 24 hours. This will likely be the storm of a letime for portions of the Carolina coast, and that's saying a lot given the impacts we've seen from Hurricanes Diana, Hugo, Fran, Bonnie, Floyd, and Matthew, the National Weather Service in Wilmington, North Carolina said. The service also stressed the potential for “unbelievable damage from wind, storm surge, and inland flooding with this storm.   Saturday 8am As it approaches the coast, it's estimated the wind speed will have reduced to less than 100mph. Florence is forecast to approach the South Carolina coast Saturday morning at 8 a.m. The storm could be reduced to a category 2 storm by the time it reaches land but this could result in an increase in rainfall to 40 inches in North Carolina. Florence is forecast to meander inland, slowly into South Carolina and could spend the weekend battering the Carolinas.
